It did me Yeoman's service: wilt thou know
The effects of what I wrote?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: An earnest Conjuration from the King,
As England was his faithful Tributary,
As love between them, as the Palm should flourish,
As Peace should still her wheaten Garland wear,
And stand a Comma between their amities,
And many such-like ases of great charge,
that on the view and know of these Contents,
Without debatement further, more or less,
He should the bearers put to sudden death,
Not shriving time allowed.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How was this sealed?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why, even in that was Heaven ordinate;
I had my fathers Signet in my Purse,
which was the Model of that Danish Seal:
Folded the Writ up in form of the other,
Subscribed it, gave it the impression, placed it safely.
The changeling never known: Now, the next day
Was our Sea Fight, and what to this was sequent,
Thou knowest already.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: so Guildensterne and Rosincrance go to it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why man, they did make love to this employment
They are not near my Conscience; their debate
Doth by their own insinuation grow:
it is dangerous, when the baser nature comes
between the pass, and fell incensed points
Of mighty opposites.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why, what a King is this?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Does it not, thinkst thee, stand me now upon
He that hath killed my King, and whored my Mother,
Popped in between the election and my hopes,
Thrown out his Angle for my proper life,
And with such cozenage; is it not perfect conscience,
to quit him with this arm? And is it not to be damned
to let this Canker of our nature come
in further evil.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It must be shortly known to him from England
What is the issue of the business there.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It will be short,
The interim is mine, and a man's life is no more
Than to say one: but I am very sorry good Horatio
that to Laertes I forgot myself;
for by the image of my Cause, I see
The Portraiture of his; I will count his favours:
But sure the bravery of his grief did put me
Into a Towering passion.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Peace, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Your Lordship is right welcome back to Denmarke.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I humbly thank you Sir, dost know this water-fly?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: no my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
Osr.
sp.l: Sweet Lord, if your friendship were at leisure, I should impart a thing to you from his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will receive it with all diligence of spirit; put your Bonnet to his right use, it is for the head.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: I thank your Lordship, it is very hot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: no, believe me it is very cold, the wind is Northerly.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: It is indifferent cold my Lord indeed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Methinks it is very sultry, and hot for my Complexion.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Exceedingly, my Lord, it is very sultry, as it were I cannot tell how: but my Lord, his Majesty bad me signify to you, that he he has laid a great wager on your head: Sir, this is the matter.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I beseech you remember.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Nay, in good faith, for mine ease in good faith: Sir, you are not ignorant of what excellence Laertes is at his weapon.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: what is his weapon?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Rapier and dagger.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: that is two of his weapons; but well.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: The sir King has waged with him six Barbary Horses, against the which he imponed as I take it, six French Rapiers and Poniards, with their assigns, as Girdle, Hangers or so: three of the Carriages infaith are very dear to fancy, very responsive to the hilts, most delicate carriages, and of very liberal conceit.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What call you the Carriages?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: The Carriages Sir, are the hangers.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The phrase would be more Germane to the matter: If we could carry Cannon by our sides; I would it might be Hangers till then; but on six Barbary Horses against six French Swords: their Assigns, and three liberal conceited Carriages, that is the French but against the Danish; why is this imponed as you call it?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: The King Sir, hath laid that in a dozen passes between you and him, he shall not exceed you three hits; He hath one twelve for mine, and that would come to immediate trial, if your Lordship would vouchsafe the Answer.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How if I answer no?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: I mean my Lord, the opposition of your person in trial.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Sir, I will walk here in the Hall; if it please his Majesty, it is the breathing time of day with me; let the Foils be brought, the Gentleman willing, and the King hold his purpose; I will win for him if I can: if not, I will gain nothing but my shame, and the odd hits.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Shall I redeliver you even so?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: to this effect Sir, after what flourish your nature will.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: I commend my duty to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Yours, yours; he does well to commend it himself, there are no tongues else for his tongue.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: This Lapwing runs away with the shell on his head.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: He did Comply with his Dug before he sucked it: thus had he and mine more of the same Bevy that I know the drossy age dotes on; only got the tune of the time, and outward habit of encounter, a kind of yeasty collection, which carries them through and through the most fond and winnowed opinions; and do but blow them to their trials: the Bubbles are out.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You will lose this wager, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I do not think so, since he went into France, I have been in continual practice; I shall win at the odds: but thou wouldst not think how all here about my heart: but it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nay, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is but foolery; but it is such a kind of gain giving as would perhaps trouble a woman.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: If your mind dislike anything, obey. I will forestall their repair hither, and say you are not fit.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Not a whit, we defy Augury; there is a special Providence in the fall of a sparrow. If it be now, it is not to come: if it be not to come, it will be now: if it be not now; yet it will come; the readiness is all, since no man has aught of what he leaves. What is it to leave betimes?

div1.stage: Enter King,Queene,Laertes and Lords,with other Attendants with Foyles,and Gauntlets,a Table and Flagons of Wine on it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Come Hamlet come, and take this hand from me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: give me your pardon Sir, I have done you wrong,
But pardon it as you are a Gentleman.
This presence knows,
And you must needs have heard how I am punished
With sore distraction? What I have done
that might your nature honour, and exception
Roughly awake, I here proclaim was madness:
was it Hamlet wronged Laertes never Hamlet
If Hamlet from himself be taken away:
And when he is not himself, does wrong Laertes
Then Hamlet does it not, Hamlet denies it:
who does it then? His Madness? If it be so,
Hamlet is of the Faction that is wronged,
His madness is poor Hamlets Enemy.
Sir, in this Audience,
Let my disclaiming from a purposed evil,
Free me so far in you most generous thoughts,
that I have shot mine Arrow over the house,
And hurt my Mother.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I am satisfied in Nature,
Whose motive in this case should stir me most
to my Revenge. But in my terms of Honour
I stand aloof, and will no reconcilement,
Till by some elder Masters of known Honour,
I have a voice, and president of peace
to keep my name ungored. But till that time,
I do receive your offered love like love,
And will not wrong it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I do embrace it freely,
And will this Brothers wager frankly play.
give us the Foils: Come on.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Come one for me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will be your foil Laertes in mine ignorance,
Your Skill shall like a Star in the darkest night,
Stick fiery off indeed.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: You mock me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: no by this hand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: give them the Foils young Osricke
Cousin Hamlet you know the wager.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: very well my Lord,
Your Grace hath laid the odds on the weaker side.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do not fear it,
I have seen you both:
But since he is bettered, we have therefore odds,

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: This is too heavy,
Let me see another.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: This likes me well,
These Foils have all a length.

sp.speaker: Osricke.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Set me the Stoups of wine upon that Table:
If Hamlet give the first, or second hit,
Or quit in answer of the third exchange,
Let all the Battlements their Ordinance fire,
The King shall drink to Hamlets better breath,
And in the Cup an union shall he throw
Richer than that, which four successive Kings
in Denmarkes Crown have worn.
give me the Cups,
And let the Kettle to the Trumpets speak,
The Trumpet to the Cannoneer without,
The Cannons to the Heavens, the Heaven to Earth,
Now the King drinks to Hamlet Come, begin,
And you the Judges bear a wary eye.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come on sir.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Come on sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: One.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: no.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Judgment.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: A hit, a very palpable hit.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Well: again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay, give me drink.
Hamlet this Pearl is thine,
here is to thy health. give him the cup.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will play this bout first, set by a while.
Come: Another hit; what say you?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: A touch, a touch, I do confess.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: our son shall win.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: he is fat, and scant of breath.
here is a Napkin, rub thy brows,
The Queen Carouses to thy fortune, Hamlet

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Good Madam.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Gertrude do not drink.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I will my Lord;
I pray you pardon me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is the poisoned Cup, it is too late.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I dare not drink yet Madam,
by and by.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Come, let me wipe thy face.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: My Lord, I will hit him now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do not think it.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: And yet it is almost against my conscience.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come for the third.
Laertes you but dally,
I pray you pass with your best violence,
I am afeared you make a wanton of me.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Say you so? Come on.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Nothing neither way.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: have at you now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Part them, they are incensed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay come, again.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: look to the Queen there ho.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: They bleed on both sides. How is it my Lord?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: How is it Laertes

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Why as a Woodcock
to mine Springe, Osricke
I am justly killed with mine own Treachery.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How does the Queen?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She sounds to see them bleed.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: no, no, the drink, the drink.
o my dear Hamlet the drink, the drink,
I am poisoned.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: o Villainy How? Let the door be locked.
Treachery, seek it out.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: It is here Hamlet
Hamlet thou art slain,
no Medicine in the world can do thee good.
in thee, there is not half an hour of life;
The Treacherous Instrument is in thy hand,
Unbated and envenomed: the soul practise
Hath turned itself on me. lo, here I lie,
never to rise again: Thy Mother is poisoned:
I can no more, the King, the King is to blame.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The point envenomed too,
Then venom to thy work.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Treason, Treason.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O yet defend me Friends, I am but hurt.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: here thou incestuous, murderous,
Damned Dane,
Drink off this Potion: Is thy Union here?
Follow my Mother.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: He is justly served.
It is a poison tempered by himself:
Exchange forgiveness with me, Noble Hamlet
Mine and my Fathers death come not upon thee,
Nor thine on me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Heaven make thee free of it, I follow thee.
I am dead Horatio wretched Queen adieu,
You that look pale, and tremble at this chance,
that are but Mutes or audience to this act:
Had I but time as this fell Sergeant death
Is strict in his Arrest) o I could tell you.
But let it be: Horatio I am dead,
Thou livest, report me and my causes right
to the unsatisfied.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: never believe it.
I am more an Antic Roman than a Dane:
here is yet some Liquor left.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: As thou art a man, give me the Cup.
Let go, by Heaven I will have it.
o good Horatio what a wounded name,
Things standing thus unknown) shall live behind me.
If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart,
Absent thee from felicity awhile,
And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain,
to tell my Story.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What warlike noise is this?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Young Fortinbras with conquest come from Poland
to the Ambassadors of England gives this warlike volley.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O I dye Horatio
The potent poison quite overcrows my spirit,
I cannot live to hear the News from England,
But I do prophesy the election lights
on Fortinbras he has my dying voice,
so tell him with the occurrents more and less,
which have solicited. The rest is silence. O, o, o, o.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Now crack a Noble heart:
Goodnight sweet Prince,
And flights of Angels sing thee to thy rest,
Why does the Drum come hither?

div1.stage: Enter Fortinbras and English Ambassador,with Drumme,Colours,and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: Where is this sight?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What is it ye would see;
If aught of woe, or wonder, cease your search.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: His quarry cries on havoc. o proud death,
What feast is toward in thine eternal Cell.
that thou so many Princes, at a shoot,
so bloodily hast struck.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: The sight is dismal,
And our affairs from England come too late,
The ears are senseless that should give us hearing,
to tell him his commandment is fulfilled,
that Rosincrance and Guildensterne are dead
Where should we have our thanks?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not from his mouth,
Had it the ability of life to thank you:
He never gave commandment for their death.
But since so jump upon this bloody question,
You from the Polake wars, and you from England
Are here arrived. give order that these bodies
High on a stage be placed to the view,
And let me speak to the yet unknowing world,
How these things came about. so shall you hear
Of carnal, bloody, and unnatural acts,
Of accidental judgments, casual slaughters
Of death's put on by cunning, and forced cause,
And in this upshot, purposes mistook,
Fallen on the Inventors' heads. All this can I
Truly deliver.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Let us haste to hear it,
And call the Noblest to the Audience.
for me, with sorrow, I embrace my Fortune,
I have some Rites of memory in this Kingdom,
which are to claim, my vantage doth
Invite me,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Of that I shall have always cause to speak,
And from his mouth
Whose voice will draw on more:
But let this same be presently performed,
even whilst men's minds are wild,
Lest more mischance
on plots, and errors happen.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Let four Captains
Bear Hamlet like a Soldier to the Stage,
for he was likely, had he been put on
to have proved most royally:
And for his passage,
The Soldier's Music, and the rites of War
speak loudly for him.
Take up the body; Such a sight as this
Becomes the Field, but here shows much amiss.
Go, bid the Soldiers shoot.

div1.stage: Exeunt Marching:after the which,a Peale of Ordenance are shot off.
